title: Altered white matter microstructure in mild cognitive impairment and Parkinson's disease

author: Indre Pileckyte, Department of Neurology, University Medical Centre Ljubljana

segmentation: Yes, indeed, I'm going to talk about altered white matter microstructure in Parkinson's disease.
And probably the first question that might appear is why are we talking about white matter in Parkinson's disease?
There is a wonderful research going on on this disease and there is a research going on on the underlying mechanisms of the disease on the progression of it.

There are pretty well established stages, so we know that the disease progress is from the brainstem towards where cortical areas we know a lot about the focus of the motor symptoms in the disease about the substantial Niagara and the damage that happens in there.
But white matter is not really mentioned a lot in this picture, so why should we talk about it?
And there are probably many reasons, but I would like to mention two of them.
So the first one would be I could call it a general shift of the research in terms of interest in a Parkinson disease.
And this probably happens becausw.
Lately we have a great advancement in dealing with the motor symptoms of the disease that are the most visible and very debilitating and stressful for the patients.
But with more successful management of these symptoms, scientists get more and more interested in non motor symptoms.
In the cognitive, emotional psychiatric symptoms.
And we also know that the disease.
Touches many areas in the brain, so of course scientists started to look using multimodal approaches.
What is really happening apart from the motor symptoms?
So we have a data coming in.
It will be also presented today in the later lectures.
And we know that there is a functional disruption in Parkinson disease, as revealed by functional magnetic resonance imaging.
We know that there are widespread metabolic changes.
We also know that there are some kind of subtle Gray matter atrophy.
And all this if we know that there are functional disruption.
If we know that there are metabolic changes and the different areas are affected, it all points to the.
To the question.

Because probably something is happening there as well, so this would be the first reason to look into a white matter.

And this constant random motion allows a process known as diffusion to happen.
What is diffusion?
Well, the best illustration is a classical example.
If you put a drop of ink in a glass of water and you don't move at glass, it is still.
The ink will diffuse what it means.
It means the particles of the ink due to this random constant motion.
We will intermingle with water molecules.

So even if you have environment with a lot of microstructure, the diffusion would still happen is a tropically.
It means the same in all directions, creating the model of diffusion that would look like as fair, but that's a cool thing about white matter because white matter.
Is an ordered structure.
And diffusion in a white matter tends to happen along the.
Principle axis of this ordered structure.

Dementia, which is not argue anymore.

Axis of the diffusion.

Differences in fractional news atropa so instruction order or directionality of the diffusion of water molecules.

On the other hand, we find no differences in mean diffusivity or radial deficit or axle diffusivity.

So naturally because we found that there was a difference between control and patient group, we decided to divide the patient group into smaller sub groups so.
First of all, we tried to compare the controls versus Parkinson disease patients with normal cognitive impairment and we found no differences.
This is not actually that surprising, because it's pretty well established finding and it is often reported in the literature.
When we try to look into Parkinson disease with mild cognitive impairment group against control group, and we found differences and actually plenty of them.
So first of all, we saw with the fractional and is atropia is decreased in the patient group.
That is a common finding.
On the other hand, we saw that the mean diffusivity is not that different.
But the exciting finding was that the radial diffusivity, a measure of the perpendicular diffusivity, was increased in a patient group.
So this tells us that probably the huge differences in fractional and is a Tropic are probably highly related to the big differences that we see in radial diffusivity.
And finally, this so almost no differences in axial diffusivity.

We're very excited to find this differences in slightly this group in Parkinson's disease with mild cognitive impairment and what we're doing at this moment, actually.
It is we're trying to correlate the.
The data that we got with behavioral measures, but this is what we're doing right now.
So unfortunately I cannot present you a lot.

And compare them in controls and.
Old patient group together.
We already found that there are differences in short delay, three recall and a digit span book backwards.

What it tells us that probably we can expect if we pursue this line of research, we can expect to find some more correlations, and probably, especially in a patient group of mild cognitive impairment with a certain behavioral measures and.
What we're looking at right now, so we're looking just for some scales of working memory.
Executive functions memory so.
OK.
So just to make some final concluding points.
We found that there are widespread white matter alterations and we identified it in different brain areas.
We also saw that.
We compare Parkinson disease with no mild cognitive impairment and controls.
We found no differences.
And the exciting thing that we're seeing is with white matter alterations that we're identifying appointing.
The more prominent in Parkinson disease patients with mild cognitive impairment.
Of course, there are limitations.
There are always limitations and the limitation of this study is that even if we manage to quantify these differences.
We cannot say a lot about the underlying mechanisms of this changes, so we can identify them.
We can quantify.
We can say that something is happening.
Unfortunately, the method and technique is not probably sensitive enough to say.
A lot about what's really happening.
So I would like to thank for everyone involved in the study and working on this study.
I would like especially thank to my colleague Rob Barlow, who is really contributing a lot and helped me a lot and that's it.
I thank you for your attention.
